H0.text: Derived units are examples of area, volume, and speed.

H1.text: Fundamental units are the type of units exemplified by area, volume, and speed.

H2.text: Calculated measure is the type of unit that includes area, volume, and speed.

H3.text: Known units are units that measure area, volume, and speed.

A4.text: In the International System of Units (SI), there are seven base units: kilogram, metre, candela, second, ampere, kelvin, and mole.

A5.text: The derived units in the SI are formed by powers, products, or quotients of the base units and are unlimited in number.

A6.text: The SI selects seven units to serve as base units, corresponding to seven base physical quantities.

A7.text: Derived units are the units of the quantities that are derived from the base quantities and some of the derived units are the units of speed, work, acceleration, energy, pressure, etc.

A8.text: The SI unit of area is the square metre, which is considered an SI derived unit.

A9.text: The cubic metre is also a SI derived unit.

A10.text: The metric system also includes the litre (L) as a unit of volume, where 1 L = 1 dm3 = 1000 cm3 = 0.001 m3.
